awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation Research: Fostering Retention in STEM Disciplines at Minority Serving Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers at Tuskegee University will leverage the results of prior research to develop a model of psychosocial and institutional structural factors that influence the retention of STEM students at HBCUs. The current project will expand the research by collecting additional data and including Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs). More specifically, they will examine the interaction of the psychosocial and structural factors identified previously and continue to examine those combinations that are most likely to produce success in retaining students in the STEM pipeline at these institutions.  The study has the potential to positively impact undergraduate STEM education at all institutions.

The researchers will use a three-phase mixed-methods approach involving phenomenological qualitative research, quantitative surveys, and quantitative analysis of secondary data to investigate four research questions: (1) What psychosocial factors appear to affect the retention of students in STEM disciplines at minority-serving institutions? In what ways are those effects manifested?  (2) How do structural factors influence retention rates in STEM disciplines at minority-serving institutions? (3) What influence, if any, do psychosocial factors appear to have on the effectiveness of structural factors which are intended to support student retention in STEM disciplines? (4) What differences and similarities are there in the apparent influence of psychosocial and structural factors on STEM retention at institutions serving different minority populations? The new sample populations are expected to yield 16 focus groups with a total of 80-112 participants. Population samples will include current STEM students, administrators and staff, faculty, and graduates of STEM programs. The researchers propose to structural equation modeling for the quantitative data analysis and axial and selective coding for the qualitative analysis. Understanding the interplay of these influences and their effects on each other and on retention will allow the researchers to further refine the model and produce a clearer perspective about STEM programs at minority-serving institutions. 

This project is supported by the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Broadening Participation Research in Education track. This program track supports ideas to create and study new models and innovations in STEM teaching and learning, investigate the underlying issues affecting the differential participation and success rates of students from underrepresented groups, and produce knowledge to inform STEM education practices and interventions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
This project involved collaborative work with four Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) across the country (Nova Southeastern University (NSU), Florida International University (FIU), the University of New Mexico (UNM), and the University of the Southwest (USW)). Built upon our previous work in the context of retention of undergraduate students in STEM disciplines at HBCUs, we examined factors (psychosocial and structural) that promote retention and persistence in STEM at the four HSIs.

We sought to refine the retention model in STEM developed in the context of HBCUs, supported by additional data collection, to gain a better understanding of the positive and negative forces impacting students majoring in STEM disciplines, identifying the key structural factors at the four participating HSIs, along with the best practices in teaching and mentoring that support student success. The Theoretical framework resulting from focus group analyses can be seen in Figure 1 and Figure 2. Survey results reveal that:

A)    Emotional factors (e.g., study habits, self-reliance, financial concerns, coping with stress) had the most significant impact on whether or not students were considering dropping out of their STEM majors.

B)    Teaching, mentoring, and motivation are linked to psychosocial and structural factors.

C)    A variety of people at the participant institutions impacted students and they did so in both psychosocial (e.g. emotional support) and structural (e.g. paperwork help) ways.

D)    Personal, emotional, and financial considerations motivated students to persist in their STEM majors as did inspiring examples.

E)     School personnel and students differed in some of their views as to what constitutes supportive teaching, such as pedagogical techniques, whereas students and graduates emphasized essential teacher?s qualities, availability as well as knowledge of the subject matter.

F)     Personnel and student views of supportive teaching overlapped in their opinions that a faculty?s personal investment in and caring for the students is important.

 

 

Psychosocial factors and academic factors impacting students are categorized into their emotions and attitudes (emotional factors), their community (social factors), and their preparation and habits (academic and psychosocial factors).  As Figure 1 shows, we categorized the positive and negative psychosocial factors that impacted STEM students. The top lists show factors that positively impacted students. The bottom lists show those that pull students down or negatively impact them.

Structural factors: Figure 2 shows that structural factors fall into three main categories: institution qualities, resources, and programs. The institution qualities included the nature of its curriculum, curriculum relevancy, small class size, course availability; private vs. public etc. Resources noted include professional opportunities, and the importance of career resources. Resources also include financial aid and technology, and the general availability of learning resources. Emerging ideas include the need for multiple types of targeted study and technological support. Institution programs were targeted to two different populations (incoming and current STEM students). We found that correct placement in courses and bridge programs are very important for the incoming STEM students. On the other hand, current students wanted to know if they are being prepared for the STEM workforces and for the standards they would experience in graduate school. For example, honors programs, combined service centers, targeted tutorials, career and professional programs, and dual enrollment are the important dimensions for current STEM students.

 

The BPR project resulted in numerous dissemination efforts outlined below:

Publication:

?        Huang, L., Garrett, L., Aji, C.A., Qazi, M., Carter, V. (Accepted 9/11/20).  Factors that Influence African American Students? Retention and Success in STEM Fields at Historically Black College/University (HBCUs): A Mixed Methods Approach. Journal of Negro Education. 

National Presentations:

  • Garrett, L., Huang, L., Aji, C., Qazi, M. (2019). Supporting the retention of Hispanic students in STEM fields. Poster presented at the annual convention of the American College Personnel Association (ACPA), Boston, Massachusetts, March 6, 2019.  
  • Garrett, L., Aji, C.A., Huang, L., Qazi, M.A., Carter, V.L., & Rutledge, J. (2018). Supporting retention in STEM fields. Poster presentation at the Annual Convention of the American College Personnel Association, 12 March 2018. Houston, Texas.

Local and Workshop Presentations:

  • Garrett, L., Huang, L., Aji, C.A., Qazi, M., & Rutledge, J. (2018). Fostering retention in STEM at HSIs: Individual institution results. Presentation at the STEM Retention at Minority Serving Institutions Liaison Workshop, 23 May 2018. Tuskegee, AL.
  • Garrett, L., Huang, L., Aji, C.A., Qazi, M., Carter, V.L., & Rutledge, J. (2018). Fostering retention in STEM at Minority Serving Institutions: Overall results. Presentation at the STEM Retention at Minority Serving Institutions Liaison Workshop, 23 May 2018. Tuskegee, AL.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/03/2021
